properties.remarks: One to two inches of rain caused urban flooding of some streets and low lying areas.
Lightning struck several buildings causing fires and destroying one home.
Large hail was reported at several locations in and around Columbus.
Trees were downed and large hail fell at several locations.
Trees were downed and large hail fell at several locations.
Trees were downed during a brief convective shower.
Trees downed during a thunderstorm. Winds at the Air Base were measured at 58 mph.
Trees downed at several locations during thunderstorms.

A microburst, with winds estimated to be between 80 and 100 mph, struck the west side of Columbus, destroying roofs of two industrial buildings.  The debris from the roofs stretched 600 yards.  A tractor-semitrailer was also blown over, injuring one male.
Trees downed.
Several large trees downed.
Winds estimated to 80 mph (69 knots) by spotters on the west side.

In Groveport, thunderstorm winds tore the roof off a building at a pool.  A house dressing room, concession stand and office also were severely damaged.  Debris was blown onto three cars.  Two workers received minor injuries from flying glass.  Several trees were also downed.
Large trees were downed.
Thunderstorm winds downed large trees and power lines.
Awnings were blown off two buildings in north Columbus, while several large tree limbs were blown down across the city.

A downburst from a thunderstorm struck an area 0.25 miles wide and 1.5 miles long north of Frank Road and east of Brown Road. Winds estimated to 80 mph damaged 52 homes, of which 19 were damaged seriously, of which six were left temporarily uninhabitable. Numerous trees were downed and about 3000 homes lost electricity due to downed power lines. Damage estimated near $600,000.
Trees were downed.
Trees were downed in a number of locations.  Roof damage occurred to several structures.
Large trees were downed at Route 40 and Darbydale.
Trees were downed in a number of locations.
Trees were downed.
Trees were downed, some on power lines.  Four golfers were injured after lightning struck the shelter house they entered to take shelter from the storm.
Trees were downed and large hail fell at several locations.
Large trees downed.
Trees were downed at several locations, and three-quarters inch hail fell at Greenlawn.
Several trees were downed, mostly in Worthington.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: Half of a roof was blown off of a pole barn, a shed was destroyed, a garage was blown in and lifted off of its foundation, a roof was blown off of a house, and other homes in the area were damaged due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at Rickenbacker Airport.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with daytime heating to produce numerous thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: A trees was downed over a road due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: Damage was first observed at the western end of London-Lancaster Road, just east of Rickenbacker Air Force Base.  A large portion of the roof of a single family residence was removed.  Damage was also observed on Pontius Road where one power pole was snapped at the base and several others were bent over.  A large storage shed constructed of wood frame with metal sheeting was destroyed.  At the end of the path, roof damage was observed with a Richardson Road residence.  A large number of trees were also uprooted and broken along this path.  The estimated maximum wind speed based on damage is around 109 miles per hour.
Numerous trees downed.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed across west central and central Ohio during the afternoon.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening. EVENT NARRATIVE: A 66 MPH gust was measured at Rickenbacker Airport (KLCK).

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A historically deep low pressure system sent a very strong cold front into a marginally unstable, but very sheared environment.  A line of storms formed west of the area overnight and moved into the region during the peak heating hours of the day.  Severe wind gusts occurred along the entire line with multiple tornadoes occurring around the region as well. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved through during the afternoon hours of April 4th.  Damaging wind was the main threat with these storms. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved through during the morning hours of February 28th.  The main threats were damaging winds and flash flooding, however one tornado also occurred with this event. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Convection developed during the afternoon across central Ohio ahead of a southward sagging frontal boundary. Some of these storms became severe by the late afternoon and early evening hours. The main threat from these storms was damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with daytime heating to produce numerous thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:
Trees downed.
Trees downed.
Numerous large limbs were knocked down into power lines.
Large limbs were blown down causing scattered power outages.
A few trees were knocked down.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Several trees were also knocked down across the southeast part of the county. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Widely scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed across Ohio during the afternoon.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along a warm front initially affecting northern Kentucky during the late afternoon hours. Activity increased and developed into multicell clusters as it lifted northeast across the area. EVENT NARRATIVE:
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EVENT NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed across the southeast part of the county. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A thin convective band developed along a strong cold front during the late evening and overnight, producing isolated wind damage.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: A semi truck was blown over due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: The spotter estimated the wind gust.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Strong upper level winds combined with an unstable airmass to produce widespread convection during the afternoon hours. The primary threats from these storms were damaging winds and large hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: Several large branches were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through the area during the late night hours of April 19th and into the early morning hours of April 20th. EVENT NARRATIVE: Twelve greenhouses constructed of metal poles overlaid with a plastic material were damaged to various degrees.  The greenhouse farthest west was hit first by the circulation and was almost completely destroyed.  Many of the plants inside the greenhouses were low to the ground and therefore sustained very little damage.  A metal door on a small warehouse attached to the greenhouses was bent.  Balled and bur-lapped trees were pulled toward the center of the path.  Additional damage at this location included plant transport carts pulled from a loading dock into a small pond.  A small metal storage shed toward the end of the observed path was also heavily distorted.  Trees west of the damage path and a house immediately east of the path were not damaged.  Estimated maximum wind speed based on damage is around 83 miles per hour.
Numerous trees downed.
A 58 mph gust was measured along US Route 33 near the Farifield county line.
A few trees were blown down and the siding was stripped off of a house.
Trees and limbs were downed.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon ahead of a cold front.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along a warm front initially affecting northern Kentucky during the late afternoon hours. Activity increased and developed into multicell clusters as it lifted northeast across the area. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough arrived during peak heating out ahead of a the cold front in a location that had received a couple hours of sunshine.  A scattered to broken line of storms developed in an area of strong deep shear, which allowed for a high degree of organization with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were uprooted, and large limbs were downed. EPISODE NARRATIVE: An unstable airmass over the Ohio Valley combined with a weak mid level disturbance to spark scattered thunderstorms over the region, a few of which became severe with damaging wind or large hail.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A second mesoscale convective system moved through the area during the evening hours. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large branches were reported down around the area.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into a thin area of instability that had developed due to the strong surface heating during the day. Convection never organized into complete lines, but some individual cells became strong to severe. Moisture had advected northward into the area in advance of the front. Motion of the storms was fairly quick and towards the east. EVENT NARRATIVE: Two large tree limbs were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into a thin area of instability that had developed due to the strong surface heating during the day. Convection never organized into complete lines, but some individual cells became strong to severe. Moisture had advected northward into the area in advance of the front. Motion of the storms was fairly quick and towards the east. EVENT NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported the wind gust.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with daytime heating to produce numerous thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: Several branches were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A historically deep low pressure system sent a very strong cold front into a marginally unstable, but very sheared environment.  A line of storms formed west of the area overnight and moved into the region during the peak heating hours of the day.  Severe wind gusts occurred along the entire line with multiple tornadoes occurring around the region as well. EVENT NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touched down near Bixby Road between Walden Trace and Hickory Grove Circle.  The tornado struck two barns.  Both barns were totally destroyed with damage blown into a nearby field.  Another nearby barn lost almost all of the roof.  Damage is indicative of wind speeds around 70 miles per hour.
A wind gust  knocked down 30 tents injuring 15 people , and knocking down electrical lines.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Several homes sustained roof and siding damage in the Robin Estates neighborhood off of Demorest Road.  Numerous large trees were uprooted and debris was scattered throughout the neighborhood.  Additional trees were down along Clime Road, causing minor damage to automobiles.  The damage was caused by a possible microburst with winds in excess of 60 mph. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across southern and western Ohio during the evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Thirty trees, five of which were greater than three feet in diameter, were downed at the Pinnacle Golf Course.  Several trees and power lines were knocked down along White Road, and a few homes had siding peeled off. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed over central and southern Ohio ahead of a cold front.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Outflow pushing east from Indiana combined with pop up thunderstorms over Ohio to produce severe thunderstorms during the afternoon. Some of these storms produced very heavy rainfall and flash flooding. The main threats from these storms were damaging thunderstorm winds and flash flooding due to heavy rain. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.
Winds gusted to 70 mph causing roof damage to a business.
Numerous trees downed.  0.75 inch diameter hail.
Numerous trees downed.
Several trees downed.
Trees were downed.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along a warm front initially affecting northern Kentucky during the late afternoon hours. Activity increased and developed into multicell clusters as it lifted northeast across the area. EVENT NARRATIVE: One inch hail also fell in this location.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Additional thunderstorms developed during the evening hours across Ohio producing wind and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Non-severe early morning convection over the Ohio River produced a deep outflow boundary across northern Kentucky, southeast Indiana, and southern Ohio. This boundary triggered the development of severe thunderstorms during the late morning through the afternoon in that area. By the mid afternoon, an approaching mesoscale convective vortex produced severe storms north of the Ohio River. Cold pools from these storms produced additional severe storms into the early evening across much of the area. The primary threat was large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: The spotter estimated the wind gust.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Siding was ripped from a home due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance entered the Ohio Valley when the atmosphere was already very unstable. The resulting thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed in southeastern Ohio along the periphery of a high pressure system during the peak heating of the day. Subsequent thunderstorms developed along outflow boundaries from previous storms during the afternoon. The main severe threats from these storms were large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved through during the morning hours of April 27th. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on a lake breeze that was pushing south ahead of a cold front. The atmosphere was unstable with temperatures in the lower nineties and dewpoints in the lower seventies.  The main threats were damaging winds and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave combined with bulk shear and instability to produce thunderstorms during the early morning. One of these storms briefly became severe. The persistence of these storms along a convergence boundary also produced flash flooding in the area. The main threats from these storms was flash flooding due to heavy rainfall and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in the area due to damaging thunderstorm winds.
A tornado briefly touched down near the intersection of US Route 23 and Interstate 270 on the south side of the Columbus metro area.
A tornado briefly touched down near the intersection of State Route 104 and US Route 33.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:
EVENT NARRATIVE: Sixty four mph winds were recorded near Eastland Mall. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were downed. Dumpsters were being blown down the street. EPISODE NARRATIVE: An axis of instability at the surface provided a focus for strong thunderstorms to affect the city of Columbus during the evening.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough arrived during peak heating out ahead of a the cold front in a location that had received a couple hours of sunshine.  A scattered to broken line of storms developed in an area of strong deep shear, which allowed for a high degree of organization with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE:

However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were uprooted just north of downtown in the Short North area. Large trees were also downed in German Village. EPISODE NARRATIVE: An axis of instability at the surface provided a focus for strong thunderstorms to affect the city of Columbus during the evening.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of convective showers moved through during the early morning hours producing wind gusts and damage.  In addition, some synoptic strong and high winds occurred during this time period. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved through during the afternoon hours of April 4th.  Damaging wind was the main threat with these storms. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

Trees and power lines downed.   A warm front which was across central Ohio at peak heating on the 26th became the focus for a Mesoscale Convective System that lasted well into the early morning hours on the 27th.  Severe thunderstorms moved repeatedly over the same areas causing substantial damage.  The continuous rainfall also caused flash flooding in Licking county.  Over 400 homes received damage from the combined severe thunderstorm and flooding event.
Winds gusted to 61 mph as reported by a storm spotter.
Several trees and large limbs were also knocked down.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through central Ohio during the evening.  Two tornadoes occurred in the Columbus metro area as the squall line moved through.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A severe mesoscale convective system moved across the southern half of the forecast area during the early morning.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 17th. Damaging winds and hail were associated with the severe thunderstorms. EVENT NARRATIVE: Hail from 0.75 to 0.88 inches fell near Bexley.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Non-severe early morning convection over the Ohio River produced a deep outflow boundary across northern Kentucky, southeast Indiana, and southern Ohio. This boundary triggered the development of severe thunderstorms during the late morning through the afternoon in that area. By the mid afternoon, an approaching mesoscale convective vortex produced severe storms north of the Ohio River. Cold pools from these storms produced additional severe storms into the early evening across much of the area. The primary threat was large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on a lake breeze that was pushing south ahead of a cold front. The atmosphere was unstable with temperatures in the lower nineties and dewpoints in the lower seventies.  The main threats were damaging winds and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Non-severe early morning convection over the Ohio River produced a deep outflow boundary across northern Kentucky, southeast Indiana, and southern Ohio. This boundary triggered the development of severe thunderstorms during the late morning through the afternoon in that area. By the mid afternoon, an approaching mesoscale convective vortex produced severe storms north of the Ohio River. Cold pools from these storms produced additional severe storms into the early evening across much of the area. The primary threat was large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very warm airmass during the afternoon and evening hours. The main threats from these storms were damaging thunderstorm winds and large hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: A 10 to 12 inch diameter tree was split due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EVENT NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in a field just west of State Route 142 and south of Interstate 70 a few miles northeast of West Jefferson in eastern Madison County.  Several trees were damaged and at least one was ripped out of the ground and tossed across State Route 142.  The path length extended for about 200 yards.  The tornado touched back down about 1.5 miles to the northeast in western Franklin County near a residence along Amity Road just north of Interstate 70.  Additional tree damage occurred in this location.  This tornado was rated EF-0 with maximum wind speeds of 75 mph. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A shower moving across Madison, Franklin and Delaware Counties in central Ohio produced a persistent funnel cloud and a few brief tornado touchdowns.  The shower moved across the western and northern portions of the Columbus metropolitan area.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary pushed south into the region with modest instability and shear. The storms were generally poorly organized but managed to produce some pockets of strong to severe wind.  One brief tornado touchdown also occurred with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE: A Columbus metro traffic camera at the intersection of Interstate 270 and Broad Street recorded a very brief tornado touchdown just north of this location.  No reports of damage were received in the immediate area, but the video footage does show a brief tornadic circulation in contact with the ground.  Winds with this tornado are estimated to be around 65 miles per hour.
High winds knocked out power to 5000 customers on the north side of Columbus.

Trees and power lines downed across the county.   A fast moving Mesoscale Convective System with numerous bow echo segments dropped from northern Indiana into the western half of Ohio causing widespread significant wind damage.  During the early morning hours, the severe activity ceased and the storms began to move repeadly across the same areas of southwestern Ohio resulting in some roads closures.
There was an estimated gust to 65 mph, several reports of roof damage to a neighborhood in Hilliard, and trees blown down countywide.
Trees down.
Trees down across the county.
Several trees were downed in Scheyer Place and along North Elk Drive in Clintonville.

Numerous trees were knocked down across the county, one of which fell on a car on the campus of Ohio State University.  A roof was peeled off a warehouse and several semi-trailers were overturned on the west side of Columbus.
Numerous trees downed across the county.
Trees and power lines knocked down in several locations across the county.
Strong winds peeled siding off a house, causing minor structural damage. Trees were also blown down throughout the area.
Several trees were blown down in the eastern part of the county.
Large limbs were knocked down across the southeast side of Columbus.  There were also a few trees blown down in the western suburbs.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: An axis of instability at the surface provided a focus for strong thunderstorms to affect the city of Columbus during the evening.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moving across the Ohio Valley combined with a convergent zone and lingering evening instability to produce thunderstorms across central Ohio. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved across Ohio during the afternoon hours of July 18th.  The main threats from these storms were wind and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees and large limbs were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.  A billboard was also bent in half due to the storms.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Tree were downed due to thunderstorm winds. Two structures were hit by the falling trees.
Trees were downed.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE:
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front across central and south central Ohio during the afternoon and evening.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed to the west of downtown Columbus. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak mid level disturbance passed over an axis of surface based instability in western Ohio. Thunderstorms that developed as a result of these factors produced damaging winds, large hail, and very heavy rainfall.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening. EVENT NARRATIVE: A 66 MPH gust was measured at the Port Columbus International Airport (KCMH).
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 17th. Damaging winds and hail were associated with the severe thunderstorms. EVENT NARRATIVE:
EPISODE NARRATIVE: A second mesoscale convective system moved through the area during the evening hours. EVENT NARRATIVE: The spotter estimated the wind gust.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very unstable air mass was in place with temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the upper 70s.  While forcing was weak, there was enough lift ahead of a mid-level impulse to spark widespread convection in the form of a mesoscale convective system. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: The atmosphere eventually recovered from the passage of an outflow boundary in the morning.  Storms developed along a convergent axis ahead of a surface trough.  Lift was aided by an enhanced short wave moving across Indiana. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on a lake breeze that was pushing south ahead of a cold front. The atmosphere was unstable with temperatures in the lower nineties and dewpoints in the lower seventies.  The main threats were damaging winds and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: A large tree was uprooted due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at Port Columbus International Airport.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on The Ohio State University campus due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front, with modest shear and instability in place. The severe weather threat from these storms was large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front, with modest shear and instability in place. The severe weather threat from these storms was large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moving across the Ohio Valley combined with a convergent zone and lingering evening instability to produce thunderstorms across central Ohio. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front, with modest shear and instability in place. The severe weather threat from these storms was large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:
Observer reported wind gust.
Thunderstorm winds gusted to 61 mph at the Columbus International Airport knocking over a trailer which was on airport grounds.  Trees were also knocked down near the airport in the town of Bexley.
Trees were blown down just south of Port Columbus International Airport.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Large hail fell for up to ten minutes and covered the ground in spots across much of the western half of the Columbus metropolitan area. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms affected central Ohio during the afternoon and evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Hail up to hen egg size fell for up to 15 minutes across the eastern Columbus suburbs, causing extensive widespread damage to vehicles, homes and other structures.  The hail accumulated up to several inches deep in spots, and remained on the ground well after the thunderstorm had passed. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms affected central Ohio during the afternoon and evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Several trees and large limbs were downed as well in downtown Columbus. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms affected central Ohio during the afternoon and evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail fell for five to ten minutes across eastern Franklin county and covered the ground.  Several homes and structures sustained damage from the hail. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms affected central Ohio during the afternoon and evening ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Penny to golf ball size hail fell from downtown Columbus into the eastern suburbs. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across southern and western Ohio during the evening ahead of a cold front.
EPISODE NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms continued to move across central and west central Ohio.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along a warm front initially affecting northern Kentucky during the late afternoon hours. Activity increased and developed into multicell clusters as it lifted northeast across the area. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along a warm front initially affecting northern Kentucky during the late afternoon hours. Activity increased and developed into multicell clusters as it lifted northeast across the area. EVENT NARRATIVE: One inch hail also fell in this location.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary along the Ohio River provided a focus for thunderstorm activity ahead of a cold front. This translated to a weak trough axis that extended from northern Kentucky to central Ohio later in the day, also providing a focus for strong storms. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EVENT NARRATIVE: Four large trees were knocked down at the Raymond Memorial Golf Course. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through central Ohio during the evening.  Two tornadoes occurred in the Columbus metro area as the squall line moved through.
EVENT NARRATIVE: A few structures sustained minor damage.  Large tree limbs were downed as well. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the evening ahead of a cold front.
EVENT NARRATIVE: A few large tree limbs were knocked down. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system dropped southeast across west central and central Ohio during the early morning.
EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were downed. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms continued to move across central and west central Ohio.

EVENT NARRATIVE: One tree and power lines were downed near the intersection of State Route 104 and Frank Road. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed over central and southern Ohio ahead of a cold front.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Three trees were knocked down, one in Clintonville and two in Westerville. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A squall line dropped southeast out of northern Indiana during the late evening of the 4th and progressed across the northern half of the forecast area overnight, producing scattered wind damage.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very unstable air mass was in place with temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the upper 70s.  While forcing was weak, there was enough lift ahead of a mid-level impulse to spark widespread convection in the form of a mesoscale convective system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large branches were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: The atmosphere eventually recovered from the passage of an outflow boundary in the morning.  Storms developed along a convergent axis ahead of a surface trough.  Lift was aided by an enhanced short wave moving across Indiana. EVENT NARRATIVE: Damage occurred to the roof of a grocery store and trees were uprooted due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary pushed south into the region with modest instability and shear. The storms were generally poorly organized but managed to produce some pockets of strong to severe wind.  One brief tornado touchdown also occurred with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large branches were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary pushed south into the region with modest instability and shear. The storms were generally poorly organized but managed to produce some pockets of strong to severe wind.  One brief tornado touchdown also occurred with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree branches and a tree were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A line of convective showers moved through during the early morning hours producing wind gusts and damage.  In addition, some synoptic strong and high winds occurred during this time period. EVENT NARRATIVE: Several large tree branches were broken due to the winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on a lake breeze that was pushing south ahead of a cold front. The atmosphere was unstable with temperatures in the lower nineties and dewpoints in the lower seventies.  The main threats were damaging winds and hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Non-severe early morning convection over the Ohio River produced a deep outflow boundary across northern Kentucky, southeast Indiana, and southern Ohio. This boundary triggered the development of severe thunderstorms during the late morning through the afternoon in that area. By the mid afternoon, an approaching mesoscale convective vortex produced severe storms north of the Ohio River. Cold pools from these storms produced additional severe storms into the early evening across much of the area. The primary threat was large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a house. Large tree limbs were also reported down in the area. These occurrences were due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An approaching shortwave trough combined with ample instability in a warm and moist air mass across Ohio and Northern Kentucky during the afternoon. This led to the development of severe thunderstorms that also produced flash flooding across central Ohio and Northern Kentucky into the evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding. EVENT NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported down on top of a car due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Widespread tree damage occurred in the area due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with daytime heating to produce numerous thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The main threats from these storms were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: Multiple trees six inches in diameter were reported down near Gahanna due to damaging thunderstorm winds.
Trees and power lines knocked down.
Numerous trees downed.  Nickel size hail also occurred.
Two large trees were downed, one falling across Morse Road.
Two large trees were downed...one blocking Morse Road.
Large tree limbs were downed.
Several trees and large limbs were knocked down.
Quarter size hail reported covering the ground in Hilliard and on west side of Columbus
Event occurred on the southeast side of town.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:
Numerous trees downed.
Several trees and large limbs downed.  Barn destroyed.
Tree and power lines downed.
Trees downed.

Trees down on the south side of Columbus.   A deep low pressure system across the western Great Lakes pushed a strong cold front across the Ohio Valley.  Just ahead of the front, a solid squall line pushed across Ohio causing widespread tree and power line damage from wind gusts of 60 to occasionally 70 mph.
Several power lines were knocked down on the south side of Columbus.

Trees and powerlines were knocked down in the Blendon Township area northeast of the city.   A cold front pushed east from Illinois and Indiana during the afternoon hours and combined with a vigorous upper level disturbance that dropped into the Ohio Valley from the lower Great Lakes region. These factors prompted a squall line to develop ahead of the cold front that moved southeast through the Wilmington Ohio (ILN) county warning area before entering northeast Kentucky and southeast Ohio.

Numerous trees and power lines were knocked down around the county, especially around Dublin.  Also around Dublin, a roof of a strip mall was damaged and a tree fell on a home. A spotter reported a wind gust to 60 mph in Hilliard and dime size hail was reported in Reynoldsburg. A 100 foot tree was knocked down on to a tent at Ohio State University.  Four workers were injured.   Two clusters of thunderstorms caused significant damage on the 9th.  During the morning hours, a large bow echo raced across the area causing widespread wind damage.  During the afternoon and evening hours, a large cluster of storms formed causing widespread wind damage and hail along with some flooding.
Numerous trees and utility poles were downed across the county.
A wind gust of 63 mph was measured at WCMH NBC 4 in Columbus.
Twelve large trees measuring one to two feet in diameter, were knocked down in the Hilltop area.
A brief microburst cause minor damage to some homes, along with downed trees and poowerlines.  Three barns in the area also sustained some minor structural damage.

Widespread wind damage occurred across the northern part of the county.  Up to 200 trees were downed, some causing extensive damage by falling onto homes and automobiles.  Dime size hail also fell across the northern Columbus suburbs.  Wind gusts were estimated at near 70 mph.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed on the northwest side of Columbus.
Large limbs were knocked down.  Penny size hail also occurred.
Several ten inch diameter trees were downed.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon across central Ohio in advance of a cold front. EVENT NARRATIVE: The New Albany Fire Department also estimated 60 mph wind gusts as the storms moved through.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An upper level jet stream tracking through the Ohio Valley combined with low pressure at the surface to produce severe thunderstorms during the afternoon of March 23rd. Several supercells developed producing large hail.  There were also a few thunderstorm line segments with damaging wind gusts ahead of drier air rapidly advancing from the west. A second round of thunderstorms occurred closer to the main cold front during the evening of March 23rd to just after midnight on March 24th. EVENT NARRATIVE:

The storms were generally poorly organized but managed to produce some pockets of strong to severe wind.  One brief tornado touchdown also occurred with the storms. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were uprooted and several others partially downed on Cranston Drive due to thunderstorm winds.

EVENT NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down and moved through the Upper Albany West subdivision.  Sixty-seven homes were damaged, sixteen of those severely and an additional eight completely destroyed.  Many of the homes sustained significant roof, siding and window damage.  Much of the damage was F1, with some low end F2 damage to around 120 mph. EPISODE NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through central Ohio during the evening.  Two tornadoes occurred in the Columbus metro area as the squall line moved through.
Several trees were knocked down in the far northeast part of the county.
Numerous trees were knocked down.
One inch hail was also reported. Trees were knocked down, and a few were stripped by the larger 1.25 inch hail.

Nickel size hail fell and some trees were knocked down in Dublin.   Two clusters of thunderstorms caused significant damage on the 9th.  During the morning hours, a large bow echo raced across the area causing widespread wind damage.  During the afternoon and evening hours, a large cluster of storms formed causing widespread wind damage and hail along with some flooding.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed in southeastern Ohio along the periphery of a high pressure system during the peak heating of the day. Subsequent thunderstorms developed along outflow boundaries from previous storms during the afternoon. The main severe threats from these storms were large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. EVENT NARRATIVE:

EVENT NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were downed.  One tree 60 feet tall and three feet in diameter was knocked down as well. EPISODE NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front across central and south central Ohio during the afternoon and evening.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very hot and potentially unstable airmass interacted with northwesterly flow aloft to produce a derecho across northern Illinois. This derecho then moved rapidly east southeast across the Ohio Valley producing widespread straight line wind damage. This rare derecho affected nearly every county in southeast Indiana, northern Kentucky, and southwestern Ohio with severe winds. This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EVENT NARRATIVE: Numerous large limbs were downed and shingles were ripped off homes near Interstate 270 and Cleveland Avenue due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very warm airmass during the afternoon and evening hours. The main threats from these storms were damaging thunderstorm winds and large hail. EVENT NARRATIVE: Three trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with daytime heating on the southern edge of a passing disturbance. Some of these storms became severe. The main threat from these storms was large hail. However, isolated damaging thunderstorm winds and localized flooding due to heavy rainfall were also possible. EVENT NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

A tornado made a brief touchdown in an area where downbursts were also occurring.  Several homes received minor damage and numerous trees were downed.   A low pressure system with an unusually strong mid and upper level jet streak was moving across the Great Lakes with an associated cold front moving across the upper Ohio valley.  Thunderstorms developed across Indiana and moved into West-Central Ohio around mid-afternoon with a distinct bow echo causing wind damage from near to Lima to southeast of Columbus.  On the southern edge of the first line of storms, a supercell developed over Central Indiana.  This storm evolved into a bow echo and swept across the Dayton metro area causing extensive wind damage and a brief tornado in Greene county.  Another supercell developed near Cincinnati and moved southeastward along the Ohio River.  This storm produced the F3 tornado in Clermont county.
Numerous trees downed.
Numerous trees and power lines downed.

A three block area of a neighborhood received extensive damage from a downburst.  Major structural damage occurred to 8 homes while 37 other homes received minor damage.  Numerous trees were downed.  One injury occurred when debris was blown through a window into a child's bedroom.
A storm left a long narrow path of damage across the county.  Numerous trees and power lines were downed and an office trailer was overturned.
Trees downed.
Winds gusted to 70 mph across the northern part of the county causing downed trees and power lines.
Numerous trees downed.  Three-quarter inch hail also fell.
Strong winds caused downed trees just east of Dublin.  Also, dime size hail occurred in Columbus, Hilliard, and Westerville.
Trees up to one foot in diameter and a few power poles were blown down near the intersection of Interstate 71 and North Broadway.

A large swath of trees were downed across the northern Columbus suburbs, with major damage to several homes and buildings from falling trees.  More trees were downed on the southeast side of Columbus.

Hail up to the size of golf balls affected the north side of the Columbus metro area and southern Delaware county.  Hail was extensive from Dublin, through Worthington and Powell, to Westerville.  Trees and shrubs were stripped of their foliage and cars and homes sustained significant hail damage.  The hail covered the ground in some locations up to six inches deep in Worthington in northern Franklin county and near the Polaris Mall in southern Delaware county.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A very unstable air mass was in place with temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the upper 70s.  While forcing was weak, there was enough lift ahead of a mid-level impulse to spark widespread convection in the form of a mesoscale convective system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: The atmosphere eventually recovered from the passage of an outflow boundary in the morning.  Storms developed along a convergent axis ahead of a surface trough.  Lift was aided by an enhanced short wave moving across Indiana. EVENT NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated the wind gust.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: A weak boundary draped across central Ohio combined with large amounts of convective available potential energy to produce severe thunderstorms across central Ohio. Most of the activity occurred during the afternoon and early evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail and damaging winds. EVENT NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was broken due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

This caused widespread power outages that lasted several days in some locations. Isolated large hail also occurred with the stronger portions of the system. EVENT NARRATIVE: Trees were downed due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE NARRATIVE: An approaching shortwave trough combined with ample instability in a warm and moist air mass across Ohio and Northern Kentucky during the afternoon. This led to the development of severe thunderstorms that also produced flash flooding across central Ohio and Northern Kentucky into the evening hours. The main severe weather threats were large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding. EVENT NARRATIVE:
